overview_summary: All five profiled neighbors are private landowners in the Potomac District with no recorded public stance on the proposed development. None serve in elected or civic leadership roles, so community influence among them is low. Outreach should be personalized and address common rural resident concerns.

neighbors.name: Todd A. Gladfelter and Karen Gladfelter
neighbors.claims: Todd A. Gladfelter (age 57) and his wife Karen reside in Hedgesville, WV, and are listed as owners of a Potomac District property in Berkeley County [Veripages](https://veripages.com/name/Todd/Gladfelter/). The Gladfelters live along Michelle Drive, a rural subdivision of ~1-acre residential lots in northwest Berkeley County [Zillow](https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/373-Michelle-Dr-Hedgesville-WV-25427/2084523647_zpid/). No references to either Todd or Karen Gladfelter engaging in local government meetings or public commentary on development were found in available records (indicating a low public profile).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Gladfelters in a neighborly, face-to-face manner to listen to any concerns. Emphasize maintaining the quiet rural character of the area and reassure them that their property values and privacy will be respected.

neighbors.name: Jamie G. Roseman and Dianna L. Roseman
neighbors.claims: Jamie G. Roseman (age 66) and Dianna L. Roseman live on Michelle Drive in Hedgesville, WV, near the Gladfelter property [Information.com](https://information.com/people/j-roseman/). Public records show the Rosemans previously lived in Hagerstown and Williamsport, Maryland, before moving to Berkeley County [Information.com](https://information.com/people/j-roseman/). There is no record of the Rosemans participating in local public hearings or statements on development issues in Berkeley County, suggesting they maintain a low public profile.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Rosemans with a friendly, informal visit to introduce the project. Emphasize benefits that won’t disrupt the neighborhood’s peace and clarify how the development will be managed to protect local property values.

neighbors.name: Scott Michael Shimel
neighbors.claims: Scott Michael Shimel is listed as the owner of a Potomac District parcel in Berkeley County (PIN 02-9G0020-0000-0000) according to county land records (public tax rolls). Shimel does not appear in any local news articles, public meeting minutes, or civic group rosters in Berkeley County that are available online, indicating no notable public profile or community leadership roles as of this report. No public statements or positions on development or energy projects by Shimel were found in the reviewed records.

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out to Mr. Shimel one-on-one to introduce the project and invite feedback. Keeping the conversation informal and respectful can help uncover any concerns he may have, given his quiet public presence.

neighbors.name: Tyler James Cloud and Jacob Ashby Cloud
neighbors.claims: Tyler James Cloud and Jacob Ashby Cloud jointly own a parcel in the Potomac District of Berkeley County (PIN 02-9000-1000-4000) per county property records. Both individuals are younger landowners with no identifiable footprint in local news or civic affairs – no references to either Cloud brother were found in Berkeley County meeting minutes or community organizations. There is no indication that Tyler or Jacob Cloud have publicly expressed any views on land development or clean energy projects in the area.

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact the Cloud brothers via a friendly introduction (possibly through a mutual acquaintance or neighbor) to explain the project. Highlight opportunities for young residents – such as community benefits or future land stewardship plans – to align the discussion with their interests.

neighbors.name: Michael D. Writt
neighbors.claims: Michael D. Writt is the listed owner of a Potomac District parcel in Berkeley County (PIN 02-9G0017-0000-0000)[Berkeley County Assessor】. The Writt surname is associated with a longstanding local farm family; for example, a Lowell H. Writt (born 1931) was part of a multi-generation farm outside Shepherdstown in the county [Shepherdstown Chronicle](https://www.shepherdstownchronicle.com/obituaries/2017/09/22/lowell-h-writt/). However, Michael D. Writt himself has no recorded involvement in county boards or public comments on development, and no direct public stance on the project has been documented.
neighbors.influence_justification: Local family roots; no public role

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respectful conversation with Mr. Writt through a familiar community channel (such as a local farm bureau or mutual contact), acknowledging his family’s long ties to the land. Emphasize how the project can co-exist with the area’s agricultural heritage and address any concerns quietly.
